edge: Avatar is a type of epic science fiction film.

Avatar was co-produced by its producers.
The film Avatar is set in the mid-22nd century.
Pandora is a lush habitable moon, as depicted in the film Avatar.
Pandora is located in the Alpha Centauri star system, as depicted in the film Avatar.
The local tribe of Pandora, as depicted in the film Avatar, is a humanoid species.
The continued existence of the Na'vi tribe of Pandora, as depicted in the film Avatar, is threatened by the expansion of the mining colony.
Human beings are colonizing Pandora, as depicted in the film Avatar.
The valuable mineral unobtanium is being mined on Pandora, as depicted in the film Avatar.
Unobtanium is a room-temperature superconductor mineral, as depicted in the film Avatar.
A genetically engineered Na'vi body operated from the brain of a remotely located human is called an Avatar, as depicted in the film Avatar.

James Cameron wrote an 80-page treatment for Avatar in 1994 and the film's budget was officially set at $237 million due to the groundbreaking array of new visual effects he achieved with Weta Digital. Other estimates put the cost as high as $310 million for production and $150 million for promotion.
James Cameron originally planned to film Avatar after completing Titanic in 1997, but the necessary technology was not yet available to achieve his vision of the film.
Work on the Na'vi language began in 2005 while Cameron started developing the screenplay and fictional universe for Avatar in early 2006.
Avatar was released using several different 3D viewing formats, including RealD 3D, Dolby 3D, XpanD 3D, and IMAX 3D.
Some South Korean theaters offered a 4D viewing experience for Avatar.
James Cameron also co-produced Titanic with Jon Landau, who later played a prominent role in the production of Avatar.
Premiered at the Odeon Leicester Square in London on December 10, 2009.
Released in the United States on December 18.
Broke several box office records, including becoming the highest-grossing film of all time during its theatrical run.
Returned to becoming the highest-grossing film since 2019 with subsequent re-releases.
Lost its position as the highest-grossing film to Avengers: Endgame in 2019 but regained it with subsequent re-releases.

The success of the film led to the Avatar franchise, which includes the sequels Avatar: The Way of Water (2022), Avatar: Fire and Ash (2025), Avatar 4 (2029), and Avatar 5 (2031).
In 2154, Earth suffers from resource exhaustion and ecological collapse.
The Resources Development Administration (RDA) mines the valuable mineral unobtanium on Pandora, a lush habitable moon orbiting a gas giant in the Alpha Centauri star system.
Pandora is inhabited by the Na'vi, 10-foot-tall (3.0 m), blue-skinned, sapient humanoids that live in harmony with nature.
The Na'vi and humans are two different sentient species on Pandora.

Paraplegic former Marine Jake Sully is recruited by the RDA to replace his deceased identical twin, who had signed up to be an operator. Avatar Program head Dr. Grace Augustine considers Jake inadequate, but accepts him as an operator.
While escorting the avatars of Grace and Dr. Norm Spellman, Jake's avatar is attacked by Pandoran wildlife and flees into the forest, where he is rescued by the Na'vi princess Neytiri.
Suspicious of Jake, she takes him to her clan.
Mo'at, the clan’s spiritual leader, orders her daughter to initiate Jake into their society.
Quaritch promises Jake that the company will restore the use of his legs in exchange for information about the Na'vi and their gathering place, Hometree.
Under which is a rich deposit of unobtanium.
Grace transfers herself, Jake, and Norm to an outpost after learning that Quaritch promised to restore the use of Jake's legs in exchange for information about the Na'vi and their gathering place.
Jake falls in love with Neytiri as he is initiated into the tribe.
The Na'vi and their gathering place, Hometree.
Orders Hometree destroyed despite Grace's argument that destroying it would damage the biological neural network that encompasses all Pandoran life.
Jake confesses that he was a spy to the Na'vi after Quaritch's soldiers destroy Hometree, killing many, including Neytiri's father, the clan chief.
Take Jake and Grace captive after learning that he was a spy.
Destroy Hometree, killing many, including Neytiri's father, the clan chief.

regains the Na'vi's trust by connecting his mind to that of the Toruk, a dragon-like creature feared and revered by the Na'vi.
supported by Neytiri and the new chief Tsu'tey, Jake unites the clan
tells them to gather all the clans to battle the RDA.
organizes a strike against the Tree of Souls to demoralize the Na'vi.
Jake prays to the Na'vi deity Eywa via a neural connection with the Tree of Souls.

escapes his crashed aircraft and breaks open the avatar link unit containing Jake's human body, exposing it to Pandora's poisonous atmosphere.
saves Jake from suffocation, seeing his human form for the first time and kills Quaritch.

Cameron revealed in February 2006 that Project 880 was a retooled version of Avatar, citing the technological advances in the creation of computer-generated characters like Gollum, King Kong, and Davy Jones.
Cameron chose Avatar over his project Battle Angel after completing a five-day camera test in the previous year.
From January to April 2006, Cameron worked on the script and developed a culture for the Na'vi, the film's aliens.
The Na'vi language was created by Paul Frommer, a linguist at USC.
Cameron developed a culture for the Na'vi in February 2006.

Actress Sigourney Weaver and the film's set designers met with Jodie S. Holt, professor of plant physiology at University of California, Riverside, to learn about the methods used by botanists to study and sample plants, and to discuss ways to explain the communication between Pandora's organisms depicted in the film.

From 2005 to 2007, Cameron worked with a handful of designers to shape the design of Na'vi. In July 2006, Cameron announced that he would film Avatar for a mid-2008 release and planned to begin principal photography with an established cast by February 2007.
During the production of Titanic, Fox wavered in its commitment to Avatar because of cost overruns and delays on Cameron's previous picture, Titanic.

James Cameron worked with Fox on previous projects such as True Lies and was committed to working with them on Avatar until delays and cost overruns arose due to issues with his previous project, Titanic.
James Cameron directed and rewrote the script for Titanic during its production.
James Cameron offered to cut his fee for Titanic if it were a commercial disappointment during its production.
Jon Landau co-produced True Lies with James Cameron and later worked in his production company Lightstorm, playing a vital role in the production of Avatar.

Jon Landau left his position as a Fox executive to work with James Cameron's production company Lightstorm during the production of True Lies and later played a vital role in the production of Avatar for Fox.
James Cameron's production company Lightstorm produced Avatar during its production.

In mid-2006, Fox decisively declined to produce the film. After Fox accepted Avatar, one skeptical Fox executive told Cameron and Landau, "I don't know if we're crazier for letting you do this, or if you're crazier for thinking you can do this ..."
Fox finally committed to making Avatar after Ingenious Media agreed to back the film, reducing Fox's financial exposure to less than half of the film's official $237 million budget.
He approached Walt Disney Studios, showing his proof of concept to then-chairman Dick Cook. When Disney attempted to take over, Fox exercised its right of first refusal.

Cameron described Avatar as "a futuristic tale set on a planet 200 years hence ... an old-fashioned jungle adventure with an environmental conscience [that] aspires to a mythic level of storytelling".
Cameron described Avatar as "a futuristic tale set on a planet 200 years hence ... an old-fashioned jungle adventure with an environmental conscience [that] aspires to a mythic level of storytelling"

The January 2007 press release described the film as "an emotional journey of redemption and revolution" and said the story is of "a wounded former Marine, thrust unwillingly into an effort to settle and exploit an exotic planet rich in biodiversity, who eventually crosses over to lead the indigenous race in a battle for survival". The story would be of an entire world complete with an ecosystem of phantasmagorical plants and creatures, and native people with a rich culture and language.

The story would be of "a wounded former Marine, thrust unwillingly into an effort to settle and exploit an exotic planet rich in biodiversity, who eventually crosses over to lead the indigenous race in a battle for survival"

'Avatar' is composed of 60% computer-generated elements and 40% live action, as well as traditional miniatures according to James Cameron.

during filming, cameron made use of his virtual camera system for motion-capture filmmaking as an alternative to conventional techniques. The latter requires completing the entire virtual world after motion capture of actors is complete, whereas with the former, scenes do not need to be interrupted repeatedly for costume fittings, make-up touch-ups, and repeated camera and lighting setups.

using conventional techniques, the complete virtual world cannot be seen until the motion capture of actors is complete. With cameron's virtual camera system, on the other hand, the director can adjust and direct scenes just as if shooting live action by showing the actors' virtual counterparts in their digital surroundings in real time.

according to cameron, using his virtual camera system for motion-capture filmmaking is like shooting live action as he can fly through space, change perspective, turn the whole scene into a living miniature, and go through it on a 50-to-1 scale.
cameron described his virtual camera system as a 'big, powerful game engine' where he has complete control over the elements like moving trees, mountains, sky, and changing time of day.
Cameron gave fellow directors Steven Spielberg and Peter Jackson a chance to test the new technology.
Cameron gave fellow directors Steven Spielberg and Peter Jackson a chance to test the new technology.

Spielberg said, "I like to think of it as digital makeup, not augmented animation ... Motion capture brings the director back to a kind of intimacy that actors and directors only know when they're working in live theater."
Spielberg and George Lucas were also able to visit the set to watch Cameron direct with the equipment.
To film the shots where CGI interacts with live action, a unique camera referred to as a "simulcam" was used, a merger of the 3D fusion camera and the virtual camera systems.
To film the shots where CGI interacts with live action, a unique camera referred to as a "simulcam" was used, a merger of the 3D fusion camera and the virtual camera systems.
Eventually, Cameron stated that it was Jon Landau who was "the heart of the Avatar family" and "the center of gravity of our little bubble universe."
Due to Cameron's personal convictions about climate change, he allowed only plant-based (vegan) food to be served on set.

The lead visual effects company for Avatar was Weta Digital, located in Wellington and employing 900 people during the production of the film.

A new cloud computing and Digital Asset Management (DAM) system named Gaia was created by Microsoft specifically for Avatar, allowing crews to keep track of and coordinate all stages in digital processing from opposite ends of the world.
Weta Digital was the lead visual effects company for Avatar.
Pixar's RenderMan animation software and managers were used to render Avatar.
The Foundry developed Mari, a new texturing and paint software system in collaboration with Weta Digital for creating Na'vi characters and the virtual world of Pandora.
The Foundry developed Mari, a new texturing and paint software system, in collaboration with Weta Digital for creating Na'vi characters and the virtual world of Pandora in Avatar.
The render farm used to create Avatar occupies the 193rd to 197th spots on the TOP500 list of the world's most powerful supercomputers.
Creating Na'vi characters and the virtual world of Pandora required over a petabyte of digital storage for Avatar.
Each minute of footage from Avatar occupies 17.28 gigabytes of storage space.

The Gaia cloud computing and Digital Asset Management (DAM) system was created by Microsoft specifically for Avatar to help coordinate all stages of digital processing from opposite ends of the world.

Weta Digital used a 930 square foot server farm filled with 4,000 Hewlett-Packard servers, each with 35,000 processor cores and 104 terabytes of RAM, along with three petabytes of network area storage running Ubuntu Linux, Grid Engine cluster manager, and Pixar's Alfred queue management system.
A number of other companies were involved in helping to finish preparing the special effects sequences for Avatar on time.

Avatar is primarily categorized as an action-adventure movie, implying a plot that involves excitement, danger, and travel for the protagonist.
The movie follows the self-exploration journey of its central character, which is a crucial aspect of any action-adventure narrative.
As an adventure film, Avatar also touches upon themes related to colonialism and imperialism, in which one culture tries to conquer another.
Another aspect that Avatar emphasizes is deep ecology, which refers to a philosophy that considers the environment as an integral part of society and culture.

In a 2007 interview with Time magazine, Cameron explained that the term Avatar in the context of his movie refers to the human technology in the future injecting a human's intelligence into a remotely located biological body. He further clarified that this concept is similar to an incarnation of one of the Hindu gods taking a flesh form.
In terms of how humans can remotely control and transfer their personalities into alien bodies, Cameron cited the Japanese cyberpunk manga and anime Ghost in the Shell.

Cameron said that he included similar creatures with a native population of 'gorgeous' tall blue aliens in his first screenplay written in 1976 or 1977. He further explained that the Na'vi, which are based on these creatures from his earlier work, were inspired by a dream his mother had long before he started working on Avatar.
Cameron also mentioned that there is a connection between the Na'vi and Hindu deities. He likes this conceptually as it adds to the cool image he saw in his mother's dream long ago.

relationship between Jake and Neytiri is a star-crossed love theme in the tradition of Romeo and Juliet. Their cultures are contemptuous of their relationship, causing them to choose sides between competing communities. This theme can be seen in the historical story of a 'white outsider' falling in love with the chief's daughter, who becomes his guide to the tribe and to their special bond with nature.

Cameron felt that whether or not the Jake and Neytiri love story would be perceived as believable partially hinged on the physical attractiveness of Neytiri's alien appearance, which was developed by considering her appeal to the all-male crew of artists. Although Cameron felt Jake and Neytiri do not fall in love right away, Worthington and Saldana felt the characters did.
For the film's floating 'Hallelujah Mountains', the designers drew inspiration from 'many different types of mountains, but mainly the karst limestone formations in China.'

Initially, Cameron stated that Avatar would be released in 3D around November 2010. Later, Fox issued a correction stating that the 3D version would be released some time in 2011 due to the conceptual stage of 3D being in progress. In May 2010, it was revealed that Fox had given Panasonic an exclusive license for the 3D Blu-ray version and only with the purchase of a Panasonic 3DTV. The length of Panasonic's exclusivity period lasted until February 2012. Cameron stated in October 2010 that the standalone 3D Blu-ray would be the final version of the film's home release and was 'maybe one, two years out'. The Blu-ray 3D version was finally released on October 16, 2012.

Michael Phillips of the Chicago Tribune described Avatar as 'the season's ideological Rorschach blot'.

Critics have accused James Cameron's Avatar of being heavy-handed with its social messages, with some comparing it to a blunt instrument or hammer. Miranda Devine of The Sydney Morning Herald, for example, described the film as an 'ideological Rorschach blot' and 'impossible to watch without being banged over the head with the director’s ideological hammer.'
Nidesh Lawtoo has highlighted an underlying social theme in Avatar, relating to contemporary fascinations with virtual avatars and the transition from reality to virtual reality.

Critics and audiences have cited similarities between Avatar and Dances with Wolves, describing the perceived connections as ranging from simple 'borrowing' to outright plagiarism. Ty Burr of The Boston Globe called Avatar 'the same movie' as Dances with Wolves.
Avatar has been characterized as being a 'white savior' movie, in which a 'backwards' native people is impotent without the leadership of a member of the invading white culture.
Parallels to the concept and use of an avatar are in Poul Anderson's 1957 novelette 'Call Me Joe'.

Despite its financial and critical success, some journalists have questioned Avatar's cultural impact in comparison to other forgettable films. In 2014, Scott Mendelson argued that Avatar had been 'all but forgotten' due to the lack of merchandising, fandom, or any long-enduring media franchise. Mendelson further stated that most general audiences could not remember any of the film's details, such as the names of its characters or actors in the cast.
According to Mendelson's argument, Avatar's only achievement of note to be its popularization of 3D cinema.

Despite some journalists questioning Avatar's cultural impact, Mendelson still felt it was a quality film, saying, 'A great blockbuster movie can just be a great blockbuster movie without capturing the lunchbox market.'

Mendelson reflected and reversed his stance in 2022 after the box office success of the re-release, saying, 'The very things that made Avatar sometimes feel like a 'forgotten blockbuster' have inspired a skewed renewed nostalgia for its singular existence. It was just a movie, an original auteur-specific movie that prioritized top-shelf filmmaking and clockwork plotting over quotable dialogue and memes.'
Some have questioned if there is an audience for the film's planned sequels, believing there to be a lack of interest in the face of the multiple delays of their release dates.
The film had not found a fandom in the same sense as many other popular media

In response to the trailer for Avatar's upcoming sequel and the film's re-release, journalists again questioned the cultural relevance of the film, particularly Patrick Ryan of USA Today, who said the film had 'curiously left almost no pop-culture footprint'
